question: 1 (l)
sols_html:
We first take the derivative to see that

\(\displaystyle f'(x) = e^{x}(\sin x - \cos x ) + e^{x}(\cos x + \sin x) = 2e^{x}\sin x\)

Setting this to zero, we see that the function is zero whenever \(\displaystyle \sin x =0\) (the exponential funciton is always bigger than 0) and on our interval \([\tfrac{\pi}{2},2\pi]\), this occurs at \(\displaystyle \pi\) and at \(\displaystyle 2\pi\).

Checking the endpoints and values at the critical points, we have

\(\displaystyle f(\tfrac{\pi}{2}) = e^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}(\sin (\tfrac{\pi}{2}) - \cos (\tfrac{\pi}{2}) ) = e^{\tfrac{\pi}{2}}\)

\(\displaystyle f(\pi) = e^{\pi}(\sin (\pi) - \cos (\pi) ) = e^{\pi}\)

\(\displaystyle f(2\pi) = e^{2\pi}(\sin (2\pi) - \cos (2\pi) ) = -e^{2\pi}\)

Hence, our function obtains its absolute maximum at \(\displaystyle \pi\) and the value is \(\displaystyle e^\pi\)
